greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: 1 + the number of trailing zeros in n (A122840).
comment: Previous name: "a(n) is the number of digits from the right in n, when n is written in base 10, that the last nonzero digit of n (counting from left to right) occurs at."

a(n) is the Levenshtein distance from the decimal expansion of n - 1 to the decimal expansion of n. For example, to convert "9" to "10", substitute "0" for "9" and insert "1". Since two such operations are required, a(10) = 2. See the analogous A091090 (binary expansion) and A115777 (full definition). - _Rick L. Shepherd_, Mar 25 2015
link: Rick L. Shepherd, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: a(160) = 2 because the last nonzero digit of 160 (counting from left to right), when 160 is written in base 10, is 6, and that 6 occurs 2 digits from the right in 160.
program: For(n := 1, n < 10001, Inc(n), Echo(n +> ' ' +> Levenshtein(n-1, n)))

Copy the above line into an editing buffer of Notepad++ with the NppCalc plugin installed and ActiveCalc enabled. Position the cursor at the end of the line and press enter to duplicate the contents of this b-file. - _Rick L. Shepherd_, Mar 25 2015
